moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 Bb4+ 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. f3 d5 5. a3 Be7
comment: Very ambitious. On the one hand 5.a3 is a free move for white, but black is going to sack a pawn and try to demonstrate that 4.f3 weakened white's king.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 Bb4+ 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. f3 d5 5. a3 Be7 6. e4 c5 7. cxd5 exd5 8. dxc5 Bxc5 9. e5
comment: This is probably the best way to grab a pawn. I think it is very revealing to see the ways 9.exd5 and 9.Nxd5 get punished. Then one realizes that, assuming he had seen black's idea, he probably would have played it too.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 Bb4+ 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. f3 d5 5. a3 Be7 6. e4 c5 7. cxd5 exd5 8. dxc5 Bxc5 9. e5 Nfd7 10. Qxd5 O-O 11. f4 Qb6 12. Nf3 Bf2+ 13. Ke2 Nc5 14. b4 Rd8
comment: The pawn becomes a piece as black struggles to keep the initiative. However, 14...Rd8 is very dangerous and could have easily won the game against inferior defense.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 Bb4+ 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. f3 d5 5. a3 Be7 6. e4 c5 7. cxd5 exd5 8. dxc5 Bxc5 9. e5 Nfd7 10. Qxd5 O-O 11. f4 Qb6 12. Nf3 Bf2+ 13. Ke2 Nc5 14. b4 Rd8 15. bxc5 Bxc5 16. Qe4
comment: I'm not sure exactly why Shirov didn't play 16.Rb1. Did he understand that it was an objectively bad move, see some deep tactical refutation, or just prefer to return material over passive defense. It seems clear that black gets prolonged play for the piece, but I don't see how he can convert it to something before the material tells. Another issue is that white's position could be very fun to play after 16.Qe4.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 Bb4+ 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. f3 d5 5. a3 Be7 6. e4 c5 7. cxd5 exd5 8. dxc5 Bxc5 9. e5 Nfd7 10. Qxd5 O-O 11. f4 Qb6 12. Nf3 Bf2+ 13. Ke2 Nc5 14. b4 Rd8 15. bxc5 Bxc5 16. Qe4 Qb3 17. Bd2 Rxd2+ 18. Kxd2 Qb2+ 19. Kd3 Qxa1 20. e6
comment: This move really "made the game" for me. There's something about the wide open space around white's centralized monarch that makes it seem odd that white is the one attacking the opponent's king. Thus, the sheer audacity of the move is immediately compelling. Unfortunately the logical reasons for the move are not so easy to explain without getting into detailed variations, but I find this is often the case with Shirov's games; rarely could he be accused of playing transparently!

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 Bb4+ 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. f3 d5 5. a3 Be7 6. e4 c5 7. cxd5 exd5 8. dxc5 Bxc5 9. e5 Nfd7 10. Qxd5 O-O 11. f4 Qb6 12. Nf3 Bf2+ 13. Ke2 Nc5 14. b4 Rd8 15. bxc5 Bxc5 16. Qe4 Qb3 17. Bd2 Rxd2+ 18. Kxd2 Qb2+ 19. Kd3 Qxa1 20. e6 fxe6
comment: It turns out that this is probably the losing mistake.

moves: 1. d4 e6 2. c4 Bb4+ 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. f3 d5 5. a3 Be7 6. e4 c5 7. cxd5 exd5 8. dxc5 Bxc5 9. e5 Nfd7 10. Qxd5 O-O 11. f4 Qb6 12. Nf3 Bf2+ 13. Ke2 Nc5 14. b4 Rd8 15. bxc5 Bxc5 16. Qe4 Qb3 17. Bd2 Rxd2+ 18. Kxd2 Qb2+ 19. Kd3 Qxa1 20. e6 fxe6 21. Ng5 g6 22. Qe5 Be7 23. Nxe6 Kf7 24. Qg7+ Ke8

1. d4 e6 2. c4 Bb4+ 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. f3 d5 5. a3 Be7 6. e4 c5 7. cxd5 exd5 8. dxc5 Bxc5 9. e5 Nfd7 10. Qxd5 O-O 11. f4 Qb6 12. Nf3 Bf2+ 13. Ke2 Nc5 14. b4 Rd8 15. bxc5 Bxc5 16. Qe4 Qb3 17. Bd2 Rxd2+ 18. Kxd2 Qb2+ 19. Kd3 Qxa1 20. e6 fxe6 21. Ng5 g6 22. Qe5 Be7 23. Nxe6 Kf7 24. Qg7+ Ke8 25. Nc7+ Kd8 26. Qh8+
comment: The most precise, as black's king is badly placed on d7.
